Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and Consequences of Relativistic Electron Precipitation as Revealed by the CubeSat Mission ELFIN’s Pitch-Angle Resolved Loss Cone Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
The jointly funded NSF/NASA ELFIN mission consists of two identical CubeSats on a polar (~ 93 degree inclination), nearly circular, low-Earth orbit. ELFIN was launched on September 15, 2018 and is currently operating within the geospace environment. This funding will address the prime mission objective of analyzing the data currently being collected by ELFIN to advance understanding of wave-particle interactions and their effect on relativistic electrons in the outer radiation belt. Two undergraduate students, a graduate student, and three early career scientists will be supported. ELFIN data products are integrated into courses at UCLA and in public outreach events in the Los Angeles area.

The project will utilize ELFIN, together with its conjunctions with other, equatorial Heliophysics missions to address the efficacy of EMIC wave precipitation, and the relative contribution of EMIC, whistlers and kinetic Alfvén waves in the observed relativistic electron scattering (100s of keV to a few MeV energy). The specific science objectives are: (1) Are EMIC waves responsible for 0.5-2MeV electron precipitation?
(2) Are waves other than EMIC waves (principally chorus waves and kinetic Alfvén waves (KAWs)), also responsible for significant relativistic electron scattering? (3) What are the typical precipitation rates associated with various wave types as function of geomagnetic conditions?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ELFIN has explored the relative role and significance of EMIC wave scattering for relativistic electron precipitation. Relativistic electron loss from the outer radiation belt occurs by EMIC waves, Field-Line-Curvature scattering and ducted chorus waves primarily at dawn and secondarily at premidnight. The primary means of sub-relativistic electron loss and energy deposition appears to be whistler-mode waves of various types. Sub-relativistic precipitation dominates the total energy delivered to the atmosphere by energetic particles, thus whistler-mode chorus dominate the energy deposition. The energy delivered to the atmosphere from energetic electrons under all geomagnetic conditions is only 2% of the energy by <30keV electrons. However, that energy is deposited in the mesosphere where low energies cannot reach, and therefore contributes readily to the production of NOx in winter seasons and its subsequent transport to the stratosphere by vertical winds where it can cause ozone depletion and have global atmospheric effects. Therefore, the input spectrum produced by ELFIN needs to be included in future global circulation models.

Students led science operations software development, improvements on attitude determination and higher-fidelity product generation. In all, approximately 20 undergraduate students were trained this past period (partly funded by NSF and partly by NASA/ELFIN). Graduate students continued to excel in their data analysis and interpretation of ELFIN data. Undergraduate student Ms. A. Roosnovo published a JGR paper in 2024. Graduate students, Mr. Tsai, Mr. Wilkins and Ms. Shi presented quarterly to the UCLA space physics groups. They presented talks or posters at the AGU meetings in 2021, 2022, 2023 and at the GEM meetings in the same years and published or submitted papers to JGR (Shi et al., 2022, Tsai et al., 2023, 2024 and Wilkins et al., 2023).

There have been approximately a dozen presentations on ELFIN each year in the last 4 years at GEM meetings, at COSPAR and at IUGG. Numerous invited ELFIN talks were given at these meetings, several by early career scientists such as Dr. X. -J. Zhang, and Dr. Ethan Tsai. We have continued to give tours of ELFIN and public speeches at events or gatherings, including visits from high-school students and the general public.
